heisig_story: Like several of the first characters we shall learn, the kanji for mouth is a clear pictograph. Since there are no circular shapes in the kanji, the square must be used to depict the circle.
koohiiStory1: Looks like a huge open mouth.
koohiiStory2: Momma used to say: "Keep your trap shut!" This thing is shaped like a trap door.

origin_of_ch_char_book: (å‘Š, gao, inform) is interpreted by the scholars as â€œbell used by the king.â€ The bottom part (å£, kou, mouth) shows a widely opened mouth, the body of the bell and this part shows the pendulum of the bell.,If the vessels were not perfect, it was believed that God would refuse to accept the ceremony. (å¦, fou, deny) In comparison with the above one (ä¸, bu, no; not), this character is added of (å£, kou, mouse) which means â€˜mouseâ€™ or â€˜speakingâ€™. God is speaking not to accept the imperfect ceremony. A huge bronze cauldron with three legs (1046-771 BC) ,(è–, åœ£, sheng, holy, sage) reflects the ancient Chinese thoughts about the holy person (sage). This symbol is composed of a person whose position is low (äºº, ren, human) and on the top an ear (è€³, er, ear), and a mouth (å£, kou, mouse) next to them. It shows someone listening to what others are saying. In his book â€œChun Qiuâ€, Confucius emphasizes how important it is to listen well to others, especially the heavenly God. This is why Confucius who listened attentively is regarded as â€œHoly Manâ€ or â€œSageâ€. Confucius said that â€œAt age sixty, I heard and followed (the words from the Heavens).â€ In other words, he is confessing that it took him sixty years to hear Heavenâ€™s command.,The first born son had a privilege as the inheritor of the parentsâ€™ family fortune. In return, the oldest son was responsible for the ceremonies of ancestors and parents. With such privilege, the eldest son had power over his younger siblings. Therefore, the eldest son often ordered his younger siblings around. (å…„, xiong=hsiung, elder brother) describes elder brother, which combines a (å£, kou, mouse) and a person (äºº, ren, human). Together, they symbolize â€œa person who speaks or gives ordersâ€. If the spirit tablet or altar (ç¤º, shi=shih, show) is added to the left , (ç¥, zhu, wish), it means the eldest brother who represents the group praying or calling a blessing from God. Then, how can the younger brother be depicted? The creator(s) of Hanzi thought about the sequence of brothers. The character (å¼Ÿ, di, younger brother) shows a spear in the middle (æˆˆ), and a rope winding the spear (). The reason for winding the spear is to prevent slippage and to make sure the spear will not break. This character came to mean â€œyounger brotherâ€ because of the meaning of winding order, or sequence. When you wind a rope around the spear, you have to do it in an orderly way. Therefore, it symbolizes the order in the ages of the siblings.,(é½’, é½¿, chi=châ€™ih, tooth) means teeth. We can see the teeth in the mouth (å£, kou). looks like a smiling mouth. This character not only means a mouth, but also means the mouth of a bottle, the entrance of a house or a cave, and a hole, etc.,There are some mysterious commonalities in cultures from different parts of the world. In many cultures, including East and West, â€œright handâ€ came to mean positive while the â€œleft handâ€ came to mean something negative. In China, when one says â€œyou are thinking Leftâ€, it refers to wrong thinking. Right hand (å³, you, right) used to mean â€œhelp with godâ€™s handsâ€. Left hand (å·¦, zuo, left) also used to mean â€œhelp of godâ€. Both symbols used to mean â€œsacred help from godâ€ but now the meaning has changed to â€œrightâ€ and â€œleftâ€. The respect to the right is reflected in the difference of these two symbols. (å£, kou, mouse) in the character of the right means â€˜orderâ€™, and (å·¥, gong, worker; industry). In the character meaning â€˜left,â€™ it means just a â€˜tool (ruler)â€™ or â€˜supportâ€™. (åŠ›, li, power) means the power of the right hand. And if a field is added on this character (ç”·, nan, man), it means a man who cultivates farmland.,(åŒ, tong, same) the upper thing means a rammer that is used to harden the ground by ramming, in the middle is the mouth (å£, kou, mouth). A ground rammer needs two people to pick up and hit the ground at the same time. When people ramming the ground, they usually shout together. Thus this character is used as â€˜sameâ€™. This character is also used to express dancing together. (èˆˆ, å…´, xing=hsing, excitement) has four hands (å…±, gong, common; altogether) which mean people together. The middle symbolizes â€˜ramming the ground togetherâ€™ (åŒ, tong, same). Therefore, this character implies everyone standing up, hand-in-hand, excitedly dancing and singing together.
humanum_full_description_en:
like an open mouth, used to breathe, talk, and eat. The original meaning is human mouth and mouth. "Shuowen": "Mouth is why people speak and eat. Pictograms. All mouths are from the mouth." Duan Yucai's note: "Speech and food eaters are the two big mouths. "Tongue" also said: " You can speak differently." "Yi" Xiang Chuan said: "Gentlemen use slurred words and eat feasts."" Xu Shen's explanation of the word " kou " is close to common sense, but after further investigation, there is actually a need for supplements.

As an organ of the human body, mouth is of course mainly used for speech and food, but as a text component, " mouth " is mainly interpreted as a frontal " mouth ", but in addition, there are other ancient text components "äº¼" (that is, "inverted mouth") leaning down. In terms of function, the front mouth is indeed derived from speech. Therefore, the " mouth " of ancient Chinese characters is added with a short horizontal or a curved pen in front of it, and it becomes " saying " "This is a clear proof. However, the downward facing "äº¼" can also make sounds, but it is different from " yue " and has another effect. This can be seen in the words "ä»Š" and "ä»¤". As for eating and drinking, from the point of view of ancient writings, it has always been "pour mouth" or "äº¼", and has nothing to do with the positive " mouth ". For the discussion, please refer to the words " food " and " drink ".

Oracle bone inscriptions are used as the original meaning, "Compilation" 13642: "Irish mouth", which means that there is a disease in the mouth. Bronze script is used as the name of the clan; it also means speaking, pronounced " Yue ", four sacrifices: "Wangkou (yue): "Zun Wenwu Emperor Yiyi"", " Zun " means worship and place; "Wenwu Emperor" "B" is Shang Emperor B, "Wen Wu Di" is the emperor's name, " B " is the temple name; " Yi " means dishes. The whole sentence means to serve dishes and sacrifice to Emperor Wenwu.

The text in bamboo and silk is used as the original meaning, "Guodian Jian. "Yu Cong 4" Brief 4: "The mouth is careless and the household is [not] shut (closed), and the Asian (evil) repays oneself without a day." It means that careless speech is like the door is not closed, and evil words are retribution. Coming soon. "Mawangdui Silk Book. "Miscellaneous Remedies", line 46: "Not dry lips."
humanum_short_description_en: Like an open mouth, the original meaning is a human mouth.

Basic explanation of words
mouth
kÇ’u
The organ that humans and animals eat and make sounds (also known as "mouth"): oral cavity. eloquence. Articulate. Eloquent.
The outside of the container: the mouth of the bottle.
Place of entry and exit: the doorway. port.
Particularly refers to certain passes of the Great Wall of China (mostly used as place names): Gubeikou. Xifengkou.
Place of rupture: opening.
heart
mouth
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ]ï¼»kÇ’uï¼½
["Guangyun" cut after bitter, thick, creek. ]
(1) An organ used by humans to make a sound and eat food.
(2) Refers to the organs used by other animals to make sounds and eat and drink.
(3) People; population.
(4) Especially women, children and adolescents.
(5) The place where the inside and outside of the object communicate.
(6) Access channels. Also refers to the port.
(7) In particular, it refers to several important passes of the Great Wall. Mostly used for place names. Such as: Gubeikou; Xifengkou. It also refers to these gates in general.
(8) A rupture shaped like a mouth; an opening.
(9) Refers to words.
(10) Especially refer to gossip, slander, etc.
(11) Eloquence.
(12) Tell; speak.
(13) Refers to inquiry; praise.
(14) Said to be expressed in oral form. See "oral message", "dictation", "oral report".
(15) Sentence; one sentence.
(16) Refers to the mouth and belly.
(17) What is the taste of mouth; taste.
(18) Refers to the age of the livestock.
(19) Cunkou. Chinese medicine refers to the part where the pulse is cut. That is, the pulsation of the radial artery one cun behind the two palms, including three parts: cun, guan and ulnar.
(20) Blades of knives and swords.
(21) A whole composed of units of the same or similar nature; a system.
(22) Quantifiers. Used for people.
(23) Quantifiers. Used to express the volume or movement of the oral cavity.
(24) Quantifiers. Used for language behavior.
